articles.headline: NBC’s Entertainment Chief Leaves in Latest Broadcast TV Shakeup
articles.snippet: Robert Greenblatt is stepping away with NBC No. 1 in the ratings. His departure comes at a time of nearly unprecedented change at the highest ranks of the broadcast networks.
articles.abstract: Robert Greenblatt is stepping away with NBC No. 1 in the ratings. His departure comes at a time of nearly unprecedented change at the highest ranks of the broadcast networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC’s entertainment chief, Robert Greenblatt, is stepping down from the company after almost eight years in charge, the latest change at the highest ranks of the major broadcast networks.

articles.headline: Brett Kavanaugh Vows to Fight ‘Smears’ and Will Not Withdraw
articles.snippet: On television and in print, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh on Monday began a remarkable campaign to defend his nomination to the Supreme Court, even as new accusations emerged.
articles.abstract: On television and in print, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh on Monday began a remarkable campaign to defend his nomination to the Supreme Court, even as new accusations emerged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, facing new allegations of sexual impropriety and growing doubts over his confirmation to the Supreme Court, mounted an aggressive defense of himself on Monday, vowing to fight the “smears” and declaring that he will not withdraw his nomination.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Hotel Workers Fret Over a New Rival: Alexa at the Front Desk
articles.snippet: As technologies threaten to displace service workers, unions are making job protection and new opportunities a priority in contract talks.
articles.abstract: As technologies threaten to displace service workers, unions are making job protection and new opportunities a priority in contract talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bosses haven’t yet introduced facial recognition technology at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel. But from her perch behind the front desk at the pink neo-Moorish palace overlooking Waikiki Beach, Jean Te’o-Gibney can see it coming.

articles.headline: A Senate Candidate’s Image Shifted. Did Her Life Story?
articles.snippet: Kyrsten Sinema, the Democratic nominee in Arizona, has made her story of childhood homelessness a central part of her political identity. But documents and contradictory statements raise questions about it.
articles.abstract: Kyrsten Sinema, the Democratic nominee in Arizona, has made her story of childhood homelessness a central part of her political identity. But documents and contradictory statements raise questions about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When Kyrsten Sinema began her rise in Arizona politics in the early 2000s, she was a Ralph Nader supporter and local spokeswoman for the Green Party who worked to repeal the death penalty and organized antiwar protests after the Sept. 11 attacks.

articles.headline: From Farm to Blockchain: Walmart Tracks Its Lettuce
articles.snippet: The giant retailer will begin requiring lettuce and spinach suppliers to contribute to a blockchain database that can rapidly pinpoint contamination.
articles.abstract: The giant retailer will begin requiring lettuce and spinach suppliers to contribute to a blockchain database that can rapidly pinpoint contamination.
articles.lead_paragraph: When dozens of people across the country got sick from eating contaminated romaine lettuce this spring, Walmart did what many grocers would do: It cleared every shred off its shelves, just to be safe.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Kavanaugh’s Yearbook Page Is ‘Horrible, Hurtful’ to a Woman It Named
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and some high school friends described themselves in a yearbook as “Renate” alumni. The woman they were referring to is furious.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and some high school friends described themselves in a yearbook as “Renate” alumni. The woman they were referring to is furious.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brett Kavanaugh’s page in his high school yearbook offers a glimpse of the teenage years of the man who is now President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee: lots of football, plenty of drinking, parties at the beach. Among the reminiscences about sports and booze is a mysterious entry: “Renate Alumnius.”
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and David Enrich

articles.headline: Instagram’s Co-Founders to Step Down From Company
articles.snippet: Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, Instagram’s co-founders, resigned from the photo app on Monday. Their exits add to the challenges facing Facebook, which owns the app.
articles.abstract: Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, Instagram’s co-founders, resigned from the photo app on Monday. Their exits add to the challenges facing Facebook, which owns the app.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, the co-founders of the photo-sharing app Instagram, have resigned and plan to leave the company in the coming weeks, adding to the challenges facing Instagram’s parent company, Facebook.

articles.headline: Offering Manicures With Your Hot Pot, China’s Haidilao Plans a Global Push
articles.snippet: The popular Chinese restaurant chain — which woos its customers with shoe-shining services, board games and other distractions — plans to raise $1 billion.
articles.abstract: The popular Chinese restaurant chain — which woos its customers with shoe-shining services, board games and other distractions — plans to raise $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, Shang Feifei goes to a restaurant just for the manicures.
articles.byline: By Elsie Chen and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: Trump Speech at U.N.: Scorn for Iran, Praise for Kim
articles.snippet: The president, at the General Assembly, doubled down on his “America First” foreign policy. He did have a few kind words for Kim Jong-un of North Korea.
articles.abstract: The president, at the General Assembly, doubled down on his “America First” foreign policy. He did have a few kind words for Kim Jong-un of North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump thrust his commitment to an “America First” foreign policy back onto the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. But in his second address on this diplomatic stage, he sounded as eager to claim credit for his achievements after 20 months in office, as he was to disrupt the world order.
